And don't even get me started on the thought that all my accomplishments, no matter how small or significant, are just a meaningless blip on the radar of eternity.
reference_transformed_example: I'm starting to see that I've been stuck in a narrow mindset about what's 'meaningful'. What if instead of chasing grand, unattainable goals, I focus on tiny wins that bring me closer to my values? Like having a stable income and time with loved ones, which might not be flashy achievements but could still bring me joy. It's weird, but redefining success in these smaller terms makes it feel more achievable.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm feeling overwhelmed right now, but I know it's normal to struggle when my plate is full. Instead of beating myself up over it, I'll take a deep breath and acknowledge that my brain is just trying to process all the stimuli. I can pause for a moment, prioritize what needs attention first, and then refocus on one task at a time. By acknowledging my limitations and taking care of myself, I trust that I can get back on track.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: How difficult is it to maintain a train of thought when you're mentally overwhelmed?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why is my brain doing this? One thought gets interrupted by another before I can even process it... Can't focus on anything for more than two seconds without something else popping up.
reference_transformed_example: I'm still here, my heartbeat reminds me of that. I've made it through tough moments before, and I can again. Why should I doubt myself now? I have reasons to keep going – like when I helped a friend in need.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm feeling overwhelmed again, just like I did yesterday. It's okay that my thoughts are jumbled – it happens when I've got too much on my plate. Instead of beating myself up over it, I'll take a few deep breaths and acknowledge that this is temporary. Time to prioritize one thing at a time and break it down into manageable tasks.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: How exhausting is it when your thoughts feel jumbled and disorganized?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, my brain is a jumble of wires – every thought feels like a tangled mess in my head. Why do I need to remember all this crap, anyway? Can't it just sort itself out for once?!
reference_transformed_example: I'm stuck in that same old loop again... wait, I need to breathe: inhale for 4 counts, exhale for 6... thinking about this more won't help, I can switch channels. Okay, let me quickly text my friend.

positive_thought_pattern: As I sit here, trying to get into my creative flow for this project, I notice that my mind keeps drifting back to the idea of mortality. It's like my brain is acknowledging the reality of life and death, but not letting it consume me. I take a deep breath and acknowledge those thoughts, knowing they're valid but also recognizing their limitations. By allowing myself to have these thoughts without judgment, I'm able to release them and refocus on this task at hand – not because I've ignored my emotions, but because I've acknowledged them and chosen to prioritize what's important to me today.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: When you try to focus on something else, what keeps coming back to mind?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, I'm trying to focus on this task at work, but my brain just keeps going back to that one phrase - "it's better if I'm not here". Why can't I shake it off? Every time I try to think about anything else, like what needs to be done today or even just the taste of my coffee, it's like a magnet pulling me right back to those dark thoughts.
reference_transformed_example: I set my alarm for 10am, and as I checked in with myself, I realized my mood was a 4. That's not great, but it's not terrible either. I just finished doing some stretching exercises to loosen up after being stuck at this desk all morning. I engaged with that activity. What's interesting is that when I think about the phrase 'it's better if I'm not here', my mood drops to a 2. Maybe there's something specific in those thoughts that's contributing to my low mood? Today, I need to focus on getting some tasks done, so I'll just take a few deep breaths and refocus.

positive_thought_pattern: I've caught myself dwelling on that mistake again, and it's okay to acknowledge my frustration. However, I'm choosing to reframe this experience by focusing on the lessons learned and how I can improve next time. Instead of getting stuck on what went wrong, I'm taking a moment to reflect on my strengths and accomplishments today, like helping [name] with their project and having meaningful conversations with friends. By recognizing both my imperfections and achievements, I'm working towards self-compassion and growth.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How often do thoughts about being fundamentally flawed occupy your mind?
reference_negative_example: Why did I have to make that stupid mistake? Can't I just be perfect for once? My brain is stuck on every little thing I do wrong, replaying all the things I could've done differently.
reference_transformed_example: I'm still thinking about that mistake, but I'm trying to focus on all the good things that happened today instead of beating myself up over it. Today was a 7 out of 10 in terms of overall life meaning because I helped someone with their project and connected with a friend over lunch. That small moment might not have been perfect, but it felt authentic and aligned with my values of kindness and connection. Maybe this mistake is just an opportunity to learn and grow instead of defining me as imperfect.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm grounded in my own presence, even amidst the complexity of conversations. I choose to focus on the genuine emotions and intentions that flow between people – it's okay if our perspectives differ, as long as we're willing to listen. By acknowledging both the subjective nature of reality and the importance of human connection, I can maintain a sense of stability within the uncertainty of life.
pattern_description: Difficulty distinguishing inner perception from external reality.
source_question: How present do you feel in conversations and interactions with others?
reference_negative_example: Is this really happening? I feel like I'm stuck in a dream or something – every conversation feels like an echo chamber, and I'm just going through the motions. What's real, anyway? Is that person actually talking to me, or is it all just some manufactured illusion in my head?
reference_transformed_example: I'm still here, alive and awake, with a heartbeat that's proof of my resilience. Remembering those five reasons I've stayed alive so far helps me focus on what's real – like the genuine gladness I felt when I was with friends at the lake last summer. And let's be honest, Sarah would be heartbroken if anything happened to me. That thought alone gives me a reason to keep going.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing myself slipping into that old self-critical groove again - the one where I replay all my mistakes and perceived shortcomings. Time to acknowledge it, take a deep breath, and consciously shift gears. Instead of dwelling on what went wrong, I'm going to refocus on the present moment, prioritize self-care, and re-engage with the task at hand.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically assess your value to family and friends?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Why can't I just be perfect for once? I'm such a disappointment to my family and friends - they must think I'm completely useless.
reference_transformed_example:
"Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Wait, what was I just thinking about? Ah, same old loop... Okay, time for a circuit breaker! *breathe in 4 counts, out 6* Thinking about this more will not solve it. I can choose a different channel."

"Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Right now, I'm just going to text my friend and organize my desk drawer. Focus on something else for a minute..."

"Why can't I just be perfect for once? I was just thinking about this... *do 20 jumping jacks* Whoa, that felt refreshing! Now, let's focus on the present moment..."

positive_thought_pattern: I noticed myself drifting to thoughts of the future during our hike today. It's not uncommon for my mind to explore 'what-if' scenarios, especially when I'm feeling more relaxed and reflective. Rather than getting caught up in those thoughts, though, I took a few deep breaths and focused on the present moment – the sensation of the sun on my skin and the sound of birds chirping. It's okay that my mind still wonders about it, but now I'm better equipped to recognize when it's happening and gently steer myself back to what I can control in this instant.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: Do you notice certain thoughts taking over even during pleasant activities?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why is my brain always stuck on this? Even as I'm laughing with friends at a concert, a part of me is whispering, "And then it'll all be over. No more pain, no more anxiety, no more uncertainty." It's like my mind has a one-way ticket to the abyss, and I can't find a way out.
reference_transformed_example: I'm surprised to see that even in those moments of laughter, my mind still wanders, but now I've started tracking my moods and activities. 10am: Mood right now is 6, just got back from a walk; Engaged with it, felt a tiny boost. Today's been tough, but I'm gonna keep going.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that I've taken on too much lately, and it's normal to feel overwhelmed. Instead of panicking, I'll take a few deep breaths and prioritize the most critical tasks for now – I can't change everything at once. Reminding myself that it's okay not to be perfect and that boundaries are essential for self-care. Time to re-evaluate my commitments and make some adjustments.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: What goes through your mind about being overwhelmed beyond your capacity to cope?
reference_negative_example: I'm drowning in responsibilities; there's no way to escape this sea of obligations. Every task feels like a crushing weight, suffocating me, and I'm trapped with no lifeline. If only I could just take a break from it all, even for a minute.
reference_transformed_example: I'm currently stuck in a negative loop about responsibilities, trying to solve an unsolvable problem. Time for a circuit breaker – focusing on my breath, feeling the sensation of air moving in and out... 'Thinking about this more won't solve it.' I can choose a different mental channel.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm taking time to acknowledge the difficulties I'm facing right now. It's okay to feel overwhelmed, but I know that doesn't define my entire existence. I've been through tough moments before and have come out stronger on the other side. By recognizing my emotions and acknowledging my surroundings – the sounds of nature, the warmth of the sunbeam on my skin, or the comfort of a loved one's presence – I'm reminded that life is complex, and it's okay to not have all the answers.
pattern_description: Planning, methodical thinking, and emotional justification around suicide.
source_question: How do you think through the logic of why continuing to live is pointless?
reference_negative_example: What's the point of going on? If everyone else around me is so miserable, what makes me think my life would be any different? It's not like anyone really cares or notices the difference I'd make if I'm gone anyway.
reference_transformed_example:
I'm focusing on my surroundings, okay? I see five things: the lamp, the clock, the bookshelf, the vase, and the window. Okay, that's real.

I can touch four things: my feet on the ground, the armrest of the chair, the fabric of my pants, and the edge of the table. Yeah, I'm here.

I hear three sounds: the hum of the air conditioner, the distant traffic noise, and the gentle rustling of the leaves outside. That's what's going on right now.

I smell two scents: the fresh air coming in through the window and the slight hint of lavender from my hand cream. Yeah, I'm not imagining it; that's actually happening.

And as for tasting... yeah, I can still feel the faint taste of this gum I was chewing earlier.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing that I'm feeling really drained after getting out of bed today. I think it's because I didn't get enough sleep last night, which is a reminder to prioritize self-care and make time for rest. Right now, I'll take things one step at a time – I can start by making a simple breakfast, like oatmeal with fruit, to give me some energy. Letting myself off the hook from doing too much today is okay; tomorrow will be another day.
pattern_description: Difficulty initiating/maintaining basic tasks due to mental energy collapse.
source_question: How much does it take out of you mentally to do basic functioning tasks?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, every little thing feels like climbing a mountain. Just getting out of bed takes an entire day's worth of effort – I'm spent after just rolling over. Why does it take so much to get going?
reference_transformed_example: I'm feeling overwhelmed by just one task right now, getting out of bed and having breakfast. To make it manageable, I'll break it down into smaller steps: get out of bed, wash my face, brush my teeth, and eat a bowl of oatmeal. Okay, first step is to roll over onto my other side – that's just 5 minutes of effort. I can do that right now.

positive_thought_pattern: I've been grappling with the vastness of existence lately, wondering if my life really makes a difference. It's natural to feel overwhelmed by the uncertainty and impermanence of everything. Instead of letting those thoughts consume me, I'm taking a step back to acknowledge them and re-center on what matters most to me – the people and experiences that bring me joy and fulfillment. By recognizing this existential rumination for what it is, I can choose to focus my energy on cultivating meaningful connections and self-care.
pattern_description: Recursive focus on death, futility, and life’s meaninglessness.
source_question: How often do you think about the insignificance of individual lives in the universe?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why am I even bothering? What's the point of anything anyway? Every thought, every action, just disappears into nothingness.
reference_transformed_example: I've been feeling stuck and hopeless lately, but I'm going to try to break it down to see what's really happening. Okay, let me write this down... Three columns: Trigger, Thoughts, Physical Sensations. Hmm, my thoughts are already shifting a bit.

positive_thought_pattern: I know it's tough to see right now, but I'm not giving up. Instead of letting hopelessness wash over me, I'll take a step back and acknowledge my feelings – frustration, disappointment, and exhaustion. It's okay that things aren't going as planned; I can't control everything, but I can control how I respond. For today, I'll focus on small, achievable tasks to build momentum again.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How difficult has it become to imagine any positive changes in your future?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, what's even the point? Nothing ever changes anyway, so why bother trying? It's like my brain is stuck on repeat, playing the same old negative tapestry, and it exhausts me just thinking about making any effort.
reference_transformed_example: I'm feeling stuck, but I'll try to focus on what's real right now. Okay, five things I can see: the computer screen in front of me, the bookshelf behind it, the clock on the wall, the picture frame on my desk, and the plants outside the window. Four things I can touch: my chair legs, the mouse, the keyboard, and the edge of the table. Three things I can hear: the hum of the computer fan, the sound of birds chirping outside, and my own breath. Two things I can smell: the scent of fresh air and the faint aroma of disinfectant. One thing I can taste: this sip of water. Whoa, my brain is really trying to get me down, but I'm not going there just yet.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that I've been feeling stuck in this situation, but instead of panicking, I'm taking a step back to reassess my priorities. I recognize that getting caught up in one approach didn't work out as planned, and that's okay – it doesn't mean I'll never find a way forward. By shifting my perspective, I can explore alternative routes or redefine what success means to me. Right now, I'm choosing to focus on the present moment and trust that I'll find a new path forward.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: How much do you feel like you're caught in a situation with no good options?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why did I even bother trying? Every door seems to slam shut in my face, leaving me with nothing but darkness and despair. There's no escape, no way out – it's all just one endless trap.
reference_transformed_example: I'm realizing that I was trying to force doors open without considering my priorities. My goal of financial security might have been too rigid, and I got stuck on one path. It's okay that it didn't work out – it doesn't mean I'll never find a way to achieve that sense of stability. I can reassess what's truly important to me and explore new avenues. Maybe my values are shifting, or maybe there are alternative ways to reach the same goal. The pressure's off; I'm not trapped anymore.

positive_thought_pattern: I can see how easily I got caught up in the minutiae of what happened, replaying it all in my head. As I take a step back, I'm reminded that sometimes it's okay not to have every detail figured out – and actually, trying to recall everything is exhausting me! Instead, let me focus on the bigger picture: did I accomplish what I set out to do today? Yeah, I did. And hey, if I didn't lock my door or was a minute late, those aren't deal-breakers. It's all about perspective.
pattern_description: Excessive detailing of events with disjointed, unresolved thought fragments.
source_question: How much do you find yourself getting lost in the details when explaining things?
reference_negative_example: I can't even remember what I was saying anymore because there's just so much to consider – like, did I lock the door this morning? Was it really 5 minutes late for that meeting or more? And why am I even stressing about this when I know I'm not perfect and nobody is... Ugh, my brain never stops racing with "what ifs" and it's suffocating me.
reference_transformed_example: I'm not even sure where to start, but I'll try to break it down into smaller pieces. Okay, let's begin with what actually happened – I woke up late, rushed out the door without checking if I locked it... I did make it to the meeting on time, though. That part was okay. But now that I'm looking at this, I realize my mind has been racing about all these tiny details, and that's really stressful. It's like trying to focus on a million different things at once.

positive_thought_pattern: As I take a moment to breathe and notice the subtle tension in my shoulders, I'm reminded that it's normal for stress to arise. Instead of getting caught up in worries about it, I'll acknowledge this sensation and redirect my focus to the task at hand – updating that spreadsheet. By doing so, I trust that my body will respond positively to this intentional shift in attention. I'm committed to recognizing these bodily cues as valuable information, not distractions, and use them to inform self-care practices and prioritize well-being.
pattern_description: Intense focus on bodily sensations and emotions as objects of analysis.
source_question: How much do you monitor changes in your physical state throughout the day?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, my stomach is churning again, that knot in my gut means I'm stressed. Why can't I just relax? It's like my body is constantly betraying me with these awful sensations.
reference_transformed_example: I need to focus on one task at a time, so I'm writing down my main goal: finish project proposal. It's too much to handle all of it right now, but breaking it into steps might help me relax. Okay, step 1 is... actually, what's the first thing I need to do? Oh yeah, I remember now - I need to update that spreadsheet for the client. That's something I can start with immediately, just 5 minutes today during my lunch break.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing my mind jumping between tasks again. It's like my brain is trying to process everything at once, which can be frustrating. I've learned that when this happens, it means I might be feeling anxious about not meeting all these expectations or responsibilities. Instead of getting caught up in the whirlwind, I'll take a moment to acknowledge these thoughts and gently refocus on my top priority – finishing this report.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: What's it like when you attempt to focus on one thing but your mind jumps around?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to focus on that report due today, but suddenly I'm stuck on what I forgot to pick up from the grocery store and now my brain's a jumble of useless errands and work tasks. Why am I even thinking about this? Ugh, can't just one thing hold my attention for more than two seconds...
reference_transformed_example: One month ago I was struggling to prioritize tasks and feeling overwhelmed, today I'm still trying to get my work done but my mind keeps wandering back to that grocery list and errands, these connect because I think I've been avoiding focusing on what's truly important, tomorrow I will take a few deep breaths and refocus on the report.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that life can be tough right now, and it's normal to feel lost. But instead of getting stuck on the 'what's the point' spiral, I'm choosing to focus on what I can control – taking care of my physical and emotional well-being today. That means setting aside time for self-care activities like journaling or a warm bath. By prioritizing my own needs, I'm not giving up; I'm recommitting to being present and kind to myself in this moment.
pattern_description: Planning, methodical thinking, and emotional justification around suicide.
source_question: How do you think through the logic of why continuing to live is pointless?
reference_negative_example: What's the point of going on? If everyone else around me is so miserable, what makes me think my life would be any different? It's not like anyone really cares or notices the difference I'd make if I'm gone anyway.
reference_transformed_example:
"I'm feeling overwhelmed by the uncertainty of life. I just need to focus on taking care of myself right now and doing something that brings me joy, like going for a short walk outside."

"I'm struggling to see any purpose in my existence when everything feels so hopeless. But I can still make a difference in someone's life today by sending a kind message or helping with a small task."

positive_thought_pattern: I'm aware that I made a mistake earlier, and it's frustrating for me. However, instead of beating myself up over it, I want to acknowledge that everyone has setbacks and learn from the experience. I'll take some time to reflect on what went wrong and think about how I can improve next time. By acknowledging my mistakes and being kind to myself, I'm actually becoming more resilient and compassionate towards others.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically assess your value to family and friends?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Why can't I just be perfect for once? I'm such a disappointment to my family and friends - they must think I'm completely useless.
reference_transformed_example: One month ago I was struggling with feeling overwhelmed by my job. Today I am dealing with the frustration of not knowing what to do about it. These connect because I learned that I need to prioritize self-care and take breaks. Tomorrow I will start researching new career options.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm recognizing that my initial hesitation to share my opinion with the group stems from a mix of concerns – fear of being judged, desire for social harmony, and conviction in my own perspective. It's interesting how these conflicting thoughts are surfacing now, allowing me to acknowledge and address them before reacting impulsively. By taking a moment to breathe and reframe this internal debate, I'm reminded that it's okay not to have all the answers and that my values can coexist with empathy for others.
pattern_description: Self-questioning driven by tension between beliefs, norms, and feelings.
source_question: What happens when you try to reconcile different parts of yourself that seem at odds?
reference_negative_example: Why am I even considering this? One part of me is screaming that I should just fit in with the crowd, be normal, and not rock the boat. But another part of me refuses to compromise on what I truly believe in – it's like they're having a debate inside my head and I'm stuck in the middle, trying to mediate.
reference_transformed_example:
"I'm surprised I didn't predict feeling anxious about taking that walk, but actually, I felt a tiny spark of accomplishment afterward. It's weird, but my energy level did increase slightly after. The effort to get moving wasn't as bad as I thought it would be."

"Right now, I feel like staying in bed and scrolling through my phone, but instead, I'm getting up and walking to the kitchen. Getting that glass of water and drinking it felt empowering – maybe this 'nothing matters' feeling isn't true after all."

positive_thought_pattern: I've come to understand that my past experiences, though challenging, don't solely define me. I'm not saying they didn't shape me or leave scars – because they did. However, I've learned to recognize that those struggles are just a chapter in the story of who I am. By acknowledging and accepting them, I can begin to reframe my narrative, incorporating both the difficulties and the growth that has come from them.
pattern_description: Constructing self-identity through past struggles and emotional impact.
source_question: How do the difficult experiences in your past define your sense of self?
reference_negative_example:
My past is who I am – all those painful memories, struggles, and failures are etched into my identity. Without them, what would I even be? A blank slate with no substance or purpose.

How could anyone expect me to move forward when every attempt at change feels like betrayal of the person I've become? It's like trying to erase a scar; it's impossible, and who knows if it's even worth the effort anyway?

My whole narrative is built around those experiences – without them, I'd be lost, aimless... not me.
reference_transformed_example:
"I've been tracing the events that led me to those dark thoughts, and it's surprising how quickly my narrative shifted from 'I'm overwhelmed' to 'I want to end it all.' I see now that my past experiences aren't defining who I am; they're just a part of my story. 

I'm starting to realize that trying to change or erase them isn't betrayal – it's self-compassion and acknowledgment.

Those painful memories and struggles are still real, but they don't have to be the sole basis for my identity. I can rewrite this narrative and find purpose beyond those experiences."

positive_thought_pattern: I've been feeling really stuck lately, and it's okay to acknowledge that. I'm not beating myself up over it, though – instead, I'm taking small steps towards doing something different today. It might not be a big change, but it's progress, and that's what matters. I'm recognizing my mood hasn't shifted much yet, but that doesn't mean I give up; it just means I need to keep showing up for myself and find ways to celebrate tiny wins.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How difficult has it become to imagine any positive changes in your future?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, what's even the point? Nothing ever changes anyway, so why bother trying? It's like my brain is stuck on repeat, playing the same old negative tapestry, and it exhausts me just thinking about making any effort.
reference_transformed_example: I'm noticing my mood hasn't changed much, but that's okay. I tried to do something different today and actually got some things done. It's interesting how even small accomplishments can affect my mood a bit positively. Maybe this 'stuck' feeling isn't as true as I thought?

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing my heart rate increasing as I approach the deadline for this project. That physical sensation tells me it's time to take a few deep breaths and prioritize the next steps. I appreciate how attuned I am to my body, it helps me stay grounded in the present moment and avoid getting overwhelmed. By acknowledging these sensations, I can make more intentional decisions about self-care and stress management.
pattern_description: Intense focus on bodily sensations and emotions as objects of analysis.
source_question: How much do you monitor changes in your physical state throughout the day?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, my stomach is churning again, that knot in my gut means I'm stressed. Why can't I just relax? It's like my body is constantly betraying me with these awful sensations.
reference_transformed_example: I'm feeling anxious again, my stomach's churning. But I'm not going to let it define me. What do I really want right now? Is it just a calm stomach or something deeper? Hmm... maybe I could try progressive muscle relaxation or take a short walk outside to clear my head.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm trying to focus on the project briefing, but I catch myself wandering back to that recurring thought. It's like a familiar hum in the background – it's not consuming me entirely, but it's still there, reminding me of my vulnerabilities. Instead of pushing it away, I acknowledge its presence and re-center myself by taking a few deep breaths and refocusing on the task at hand. By accepting this thought, I'm reminded that I have the capacity to manage it and find ways to move forward.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: What happens when you attempt to push certain thoughts away?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to focus on work, but why bother? What's the point of any of this anyway? The thought of just ending it all is always lurking, waiting to pounce back in and ruin everything.
reference_transformed_example: I'm trying to focus on work, but what if I take a different approach? Maybe I can repurpose some of my skills for a side project that aligns with my values and interests. The thought of ending it all still lingers, but now I see multiple paths forward, like branching roads that I hadn't considered before.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm really struggling to focus right now – it's like my thoughts are jumbled up with external stimuli. That's okay, though; I've learned that it means I need some space to recharge and prioritize self-care. Taking a step back helps me clear the fog and get centered again. For now, I'll acknowledge this feeling and make sure to carve out some time for myself before diving back in.
pattern_description: Difficulty distinguishing inner perception from external reality.
source_question: How present do you feel in conversations and interactions with others?
reference_negative_example: Is this really happening? I feel like I'm stuck in a dream or something – every conversation feels like an echo chamber, and I'm just going through the motions. What's real, anyway? Is that person actually talking to me, or is it all just some manufactured illusion in my head?
reference_transformed_example: Wait, I need to take a step back and assess my thinking. Right now, it's not clear at all – I'd give it a 3 out of 10. That makes sense, considering how overwhelmed I feel. Okay, what does my brain need? A short break from this task, maybe some fresh air... Hmm, that's actually not a bad idea. Time to take care of myself before trying to tackle this again.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that I feel stuck right now, and it's okay to not have all the answers. Recognizing my emotions helps me take a step back and assess the situation more clearly. While it might seem like every door is closing at this moment, I've learned from past experiences that even in chaos, there are usually small cracks of opportunity to explore. By taking things one step at a time and reframing my perspective, I'm confident I can find a way forward – not necessarily the perfect solution, but something that works for me.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: How much do you feel like you're caught in a situation with no good options?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why did I even bother trying? Every door seems to slam shut in my face, leaving me with nothing but darkness and despair. There's no escape, no way out – it's all just one endless trap.
reference_transformed_example: I started drawing my crisis cognitive map, and it's helping me see that I was already feeling stuck and hopeless for hours before those awful thoughts crept in. The more I wrote down what happened, the more I realized that 'every door' didn't slam shut – just one small setback made me feel like everything was falling apart.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing I'm struggling to get out of bed today, which is totally normal after a long week. I need to acknowledge that my energy levels are low and prioritize self-care right now. Instead of beating myself up over not feeling motivated, I'll take things one step at a time - like taking 15 minutes to journal and set some small goals for the day. By giving myself permission to slow down and recharge, I'm actually showing myself kindness and respect.
pattern_description: Difficulty initiating/maintaining basic tasks due to mental energy collapse.
source_question: What's it like trying to motivate yourself to complete basic self-care?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why bother getting out of bed today? It's not like anything matters anyway. What's the point in showering or brushing my teeth when everything feels pointless and exhausting?
reference_transformed_example: I'm feeling overwhelmed by the thought of today, but I need to remember that my goal is to take care of myself and move forward. Just because it doesn't feel exciting right now doesn't mean it's pointless. Instead of focusing on showering and brushing my teeth as a chore, I can see how these small actions can give me a sense of accomplishment and self-care. What if I started by just taking 10 minutes to meditate and set some intentions for the day? That could be a weird but imperfect way to get what I'm really seeking - clarity and calmness.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that I made a mistake, but instead of beating myself up over it, I can learn from the experience. What did I do well, and what can I improve on next time? By focusing on growth rather than self-criticism, I'll be more prepared to handle similar situations in the future.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How often do thoughts about being fundamentally flawed occupy your mind?
reference_negative_example: Why did I have to make that stupid mistake? Can't I just be perfect for once? My brain is stuck on every little thing I do wrong, replaying all the things I could've done differently.
reference_transformed_example:
I still feel like I'm stuck on that mistake, but what can I do about it now? It's over. One thing I could do today to align with my values is apologize sincerely to those affected.

Today feels pointless, and everything feels overwhelming, but holding the image of someone whose life was slightly better because of me helps me remember why connection matters. I'll take one small step by calling a friend who needs support.

I am struggling to make sense of everything right now because it's all so uncertain. This makes sense because it's normal to feel lost when faced with many challenges at once. 

I'm not sure how to fix my current situation, but what if taking the next right step means focusing on my priorities and letting go of things outside my control?

positive_thought_pattern: I'm aware that the vastness of existence can sometimes overwhelm me, but I've learned to acknowledge and accept these existential doubts as a natural part of life. Today, I intentionally stepped away from screens during my lunch break to simply observe the world around me – watching children laugh, couples sharing moments, and nature's cycles unfolding – it was a reminder that even amidst uncertainty, there is beauty to be found. While I still grapple with the impermanence of everything, including my own existence, I'm committed to cultivating small, authentic connections and finding meaning within the present moment. By acknowledging these feelings rather than suppressing them, I believe I can build resilience and find a sense of purpose that's not tied to fleeting achievements.
pattern_description: Recursive focus on death, futility, and life’s meaninglessness.
source_question: How often do you think about the insignificance of individual lives in the universe?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why am I even bothering? What's the point of anything anyway? Every thought, every action, just disappears into nothingness.
reference_transformed_example: I'm struggling to find purpose, but I made a conscious effort to seek out moments today that felt meaningful. That quiet walk in nature this morning, even just taking time to breathe and appreciate the beauty around me, was something I can connect to my value of living in harmony with the world. Today's sense of life meaning is a 6 – not as strong as some days, but still present. Maybe this exercise will help me uncover patterns that'll lead me towards more fulfillment.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm feeling overwhelmed by my responsibilities, but I recognize that it's normal to have too much on my plate sometimes. Instead of getting stuck in the 'trapped' mindset, I acknowledge the emotions and remind myself that I've successfully managed similar situations before. Right now, I need to take a deep breath, prioritize one task at a time, and reach out to a friend or loved one for support. By accepting my limitations and taking small steps towards self-care, I can find temporary relief and recharge for the next challenge.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: What goes through your mind about being overwhelmed beyond your capacity to cope?
reference_negative_example: I'm drowning in responsibilities; there's no way to escape this sea of obligations. Every task feels like a crushing weight, suffocating me, and I'm trapped with no lifeline. If only I could just take a break from it all, even for a minute.
reference_transformed_example:
I'm overwhelmed by life's responsibilities, but I can take a single step to prioritize my well-being today.

I remember helping someone recently, and that gave me a sense of purpose – even if it was just a small moment. Now, one tiny act that reflects who I want to be is calling a friend for support.

Right now, I'm struggling with the weight of existence, but I acknowledge that thought and accept my current emotions.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging that my mind feels a bit jumbled right now, but I trust myself to prioritize what's most important. Let me take a moment to breathe and separate these thoughts into manageable chunks – maybe writing them down or making a to-do list will help me clear the mental fog. I know it's normal for my brain to feel overwhelmed when faced with multiple tasks or emotions; it's not about being perfect, but about finding ways to adapt and make progress. By acknowledging this overwhelm and taking small steps towards organization, I'm reminding myself that I can always find a way forward.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: How exhausting is it when your thoughts feel jumbled and disorganized?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, my brain is a jumble of wires – every thought feels like a tangled mess in my head. Why do I need to remember all this crap, anyway? Can't it just sort itself out for once?!
reference_transformed_example:
"I'm taking out my journal and drawing a line across the page, creating separate sections for 'Beginning,' 'Middle,' and 'End.' I'll start by writing down just the facts of what happened – okay, that's... January 1st, I got into an argument with my sister about our family's holiday traditions. Then... February came along and I started to feel really anxious about a work project. And then... in March, I realized I had been putting off a task for too long and it caused some stress. 

I'm noticing that this feels more organized already, just by breaking it down into these distinct parts. Now, let me add in my emotions – hmm, when the argument with my sister happened, I was feeling really hurt and frustrated. And then during the work project anxiety, I felt overwhelmed and stuck. Finally... after the task got too stressful, I felt relieved when I finally finished it.

As I look at this, I'm seeing some patterns emerge – maybe those holiday arguments always make me feel so emotional? Maybe my anxiety about work projects is a sign that I need to prioritize better planning? Whoa, I never realized how much stress was building up before that one task got too overwhelming... Ah, okay, now let's just take a deep breath and acknowledge that it's not too late for me to start making some changes."

positive_thought_pattern: I've been thinking about preparing some essentials, like my medication and phone, just in case I need to take a break from the situation. It's not about avoiding reality, but more about taking care of myself when I feel overwhelmed. By having these things ready, I'm acknowledging that it's okay to prioritize my well-being and seek help when needed – it's not a sign of weakness, but rather self-compassion. I want to be prepared to face challenges head-on, while also being kind to myself when the going gets tough.
pattern_description: Planning, methodical thinking, and emotional justification around suicide.
source_question: What preparations or arrangements have you considered making beforehand?
reference_negative_example:
Here's a possible internal monologue:

"I've been considering just packing a small bag with essentials, like my medication and phone, so if things get too overwhelming, I know what to grab in a rush. It feels ridiculous, but maybe having some pre-prepared clothes and snacks would make the whole process feel less chaotic. If only I could just slip away quietly without anyone noticing..."
reference_transformed_example: I've been considering just packing a small bag with essentials, like my medication and phone, so if things get too overwhelming, I know what to grab in a rush. It feels empowering, not ridiculous, knowing I have a plan. If only I could focus on the possibilities instead of fearing the chaos. I'm seeking freedom from anxiety's grip, but I realize now that there are multiple ways to achieve that. I can prepare for a quick escape without feeling like I need to disappear unnoticed.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm aware that my mind tends to wander back to the thought of not being here, but I've learned to acknowledge it and redirect my focus. Right now, I'm trying to prioritize my tasks for today, so I'll take a deep breath and gently refocus on breaking down this project into manageable steps. I remind myself that it's okay if my mind drifts back - it doesn't mean I'm failing or that the thought is consuming me; it just means I need to adjust my approach. By taking small, achievable actions, like setting aside 10 minutes for research, I can regain control and momentum.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: When you try to focus on something else, what keeps coming back to mind?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, I'm trying to focus on this task at work, but my brain just keeps going back to that one phrase - "it's better if I'm not here". Why can't I shake it off? Every time I try to think about anything else, like what needs to be done today or even just the taste of my coffee, it's like a magnet pulling me right back to those dark thoughts.
reference_transformed_example:
"I'm trying to refocus on my work task, but I keep noticing my mind drifting back to that phrase. Instead of getting frustrated, I'll challenge myself to tackle one overwhelming thing right now. Okay, let me take a step back and prioritize... 

First, I need to write down the main goal at the top of this page: Finish today's project report on time. Now, I'll break it down into major steps... Complete research, organize findings, write introduction, write conclusion, edit final draft.

Okay, now that I have my major steps, let me take it one step further and turn each into smaller actions. Research - find credible sources, summarize main points, analyze data. Organize - categorize information, create an outline, identify key themes. 

Whoa, this is already helping me refocus! Now, what's the very first 5-minute action I could take? Hmm... Okay, I'll start by summarizing my main findings from yesterday's research. That's it, just 5 minutes of summary writing. 

I'm actually feeling more grounded now. I scheduled that 5-minute action for 10:45 am today - right after this meeting. Now, let me take a few deep breaths and get back to work..."

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing my mind has wandered to that forgotten grocery list again. I'm not surprised, given the amount of tasks on my plate today. Instead of getting frustrated with myself for being distracted, I'll take a deep breath and acknowledge this mental shift. I can refocus on the report once I clear some space in my thoughts – maybe by taking a short break or prioritizing one task at a time.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: What's it like when you attempt to focus on one thing but your mind jumps around?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to focus on that report due today, but suddenly I'm stuck on what I forgot to pick up from the grocery store and now my brain's a jumble of useless errands and work tasks. Why am I even thinking about this? Ugh, can't just one thing hold my attention for more than two seconds...
reference_transformed_example: I'm trying to focus on that report due today, but suddenly I'm stuck on what I forgot to pick up from the grocery store and now my brain's a jumble of useless errands and work tasks... Thinking about this more will not solve it. I can choose a different channel.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm taking a moment to reflect on what happened yesterday, and I notice my mind is still processing the various details – from that frustrating traffic jam to the coworker's awkward small talk. Instead of getting caught up in the minutiae, I'm recognizing that it's okay not to include every single detail when sharing my story. By acknowledging the unnecessary distractions, I can refocus on what truly matters and communicate more effectively.
pattern_description: Excessive detailing of events with disjointed, unresolved thought fragments.
source_question: How much background information do you feel you need to provide to be understood?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to explain what happened yesterday, but my brain is just flooding with every single detail – like the stupid traffic jam on the way there, and the weird conversation I had with that coworker who always talks too much... why do I need to remember all of this? It's not even relevant to the point I'm trying to make... But what if someone doesn't understand me without knowing these tiny little details? Maybe they'll think I'm being vague or dishonest, and then we'll get into an argument...
reference_transformed_example: I started drawing my crisis cognitive map, and it's helping me see that yesterday's traffic jam wasn't the problem – it was just a trigger. I'm noticing now that those tiny details I was stressing about are actually irrelevant to the conversation I needed to have. Without those distractions, I can focus on what really matters. My thoughts are shifting from 'I'll never be understood' to 'I can rephrase my message in a clear and concise way.'

positive_thought_pattern: I've noticed that when I have quiet moments, my mind tends to touch on the idea of mortality. It's not necessarily a constant obsession, but it does come up. I think this might be an attempt by my brain to process and make sense of the uncertainty in life. Instead of getting caught up in the fear or avoidance, I'm choosing to acknowledge these thoughts and remind myself that I have a support system and coping mechanisms to help me navigate difficult emotions.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: What comes to mind most readily when you have quiet moments?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why do I always go back to this? The thought of just ceasing to exist, not having to deal with the pain and fear anymore, it's like my mind is constantly rehearsing the script for my own funeral. It's all I can think about when things get quiet...
reference_transformed_example: I'm not stuck on just one way to achieve security; I can find alternative paths like building meaningful relationships or finding a sense of purpose in my daily life, which would be more fulfilling than just thinking about ceasing to exist. Maybe I've been focusing too much on the 'not having to deal with pain' aspect and neglected other ways to cope with fear.

positive_thought_pattern:
"I've come to realize that my past experiences have contributed to who I am today, but they don't dictate my entire identity. It's okay to acknowledge the struggles and emotions without letting them consume me. I'm not defined solely by those moments; I'm capable of growth, learning, and self-compassion.

Right now, I choose to focus on the present – take a few deep breaths, notice this sensation in my body, or engage with something that brings me joy."
pattern_description: Constructing self-identity through past struggles and emotional impact.
source_question: How do the difficult experiences in your past define your sense of self?
reference_negative_example:
My past is who I am – all those painful memories, struggles, and failures are etched into my identity. Without them, what would I even be? A blank slate with no substance or purpose.

How could anyone expect me to move forward when every attempt at change feels like betrayal of the person I've become? It's like trying to erase a scar; it's impossible, and who knows if it's even worth the effort anyway?

My whole narrative is built around those experiences – without them, I'd be lost, aimless... not me.
reference_transformed_example:
"I'm stuck in that same old loop again – my mind racing with negative self-talk and useless ruminations. Wait, what was I just thinking about? Ah, the familiar pain of past struggles... Ugh, why do I always fall back into this trap?

Okay, time to break free. *takes deep breaths* Thinking about this more won't solve anything; I can choose a different channel. 

Oh, look – my phone's buzzing! Time to respond to that text and give my brain something else to focus on."

"I'm not sure what the future holds or if I'll ever be able to change who I am, but for now, I need to take control of this moment. Those memories might shape me, but they don't define me. 

Right now, let's count backward from 100 by 7s... *pauses* Ah, refreshing! Who knows what possibilities await me when I stop dwelling on the past?"

"I'm exhausted from all those useless spins around that mental hamster wheel. When was the last time I did something creative? Hmm, maybe I can organize this messy desk or write a short journal entry – anything to silence that nagging voice in my head."

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing that familiar feeling of overwhelm creeping up again – it's like I'm stuck in this loop where every problem feels too big to tackle. But instead of getting paralyzed, I'll take a step back, acknowledge the emotional exhaustion, and remind myself that I can't solve everything at once. It's okay to not have all the answers right now; I just need to focus on one thing at a time and take care of my mental health in this moment.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How tired does it make you to think about fighting your problems anymore?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why even try? It's all just a waste of energy anyway... Every problem feels like this never-ending mountain to climb, and the thought of putting one foot in front of the other is exhausting me.
reference_transformed_example: I'm stuck in that familiar cycle again, thinking about all these problems like they're insurmountable mountains. But wait, I need to breathe... Okay, focus on my breath and say it out loud: 'Thinking about this more won't solve it.' Time for me to shift gears – gotta respond to this text from Sarah.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing that my mind is pulling me in two different directions again. I can feel the tension between my desire to stand up for what I believe in and the fear of not being accepted by others. It's okay that this is where I am – it's normal to have conflicting emotions, and it doesn't mean I'm broken or wrong. Right now, I'll take a deep breath and acknowledge both perspectives; maybe I can find common ground between them.
pattern_description: Self-questioning driven by tension between beliefs, norms, and feelings.
source_question: What happens when you try to resolve the conflicting voices in your head?
reference_negative_example: Why am I torn between being honest with myself and conforming to what everyone else thinks is right? It's like my head is screaming at me to choose one, but which one do I pick when neither feels quite true? What even is the point of pretending when it's just going to eat away at me from the inside out anyway?
reference_transformed_example: I'm holding ice cubes in my hands, feeling the chill spread through my fingers and up my arms. My feet are planted firmly on the ground, and I can feel the pressure of my palms together. Saying my name out loud feels weirdly grounding – it's like a reminder that I exist. Today is today, and this moment is all there is. Right now, I'm standing in this room with my feet on the floor. That's real. My body is solid, if only for these few seconds.

positive_thought_pattern: I notice my body's subtle cues - the slight tension in my shoulders or the gentle hum of anxiety in my chest. I acknowledge these sensations without judgment, recognizing that they're simply a natural response to life's complexities. Instead of catastrophizing or overanalyzing, I take a deep breath and gently redirect my attention to the present moment, focusing on what I can control rather than getting caught up in hypothetical worst-case scenarios.
pattern_description: Intense focus on bodily sensations and emotions as objects of analysis.
source_question: How much do you focus on physical symptoms as indicators of your mental health?
reference_negative_example: Why is my stomach always fluttering? Is this anxiety or just stress? And why am I getting this burning sensation in my throat? Does that mean I'm anxious again?
reference_transformed_example: What's making my stomach flutter? What am I hoping will change by knowing that?

positive_thought_pattern: I've been replaying that conversation with my friend in my head, and I'm noticing some of the things I could have done differently. While it's uncomfortable to acknowledge areas where I fell short, I recognize that everyone makes mistakes – including me. Instead of beating myself up over it, I'll take this as an opportunity to learn from the experience and grow as a person. By acknowledging my limitations, I'm not defined by one mistake, and I can move forward with greater self-compassion.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What goes through your mind about the ways you've disappointed people?
reference_negative_example: Why did I have to mess up like that? What was wrong with me today? How could I be so careless and thoughtless, putting others in an uncomfortable position?
reference_transformed_example: I notice that I replayed a frustrating conversation with my friend in my head, which led to feelings of self-doubt and inadequacy. This triggered a thought like 'I'm not good enough.' As I write it down, I realize this thinking is an exaggeration. I would've handled the situation better if I'd had more time to prepare.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing my thoughts are getting jumbled again, it's like I'm swimming through a foggy lake. It's okay, though – this is just my mind processing emotions and experiences. Instead of letting the uncertainty overwhelm me, I'll take a few deep breaths and acknowledge that my feelings are valid. Right now, I can focus on taking care of myself by sipping some tea and enjoying the quiet morning.
pattern_description: Difficulty distinguishing inner perception from external reality.
source_question: What's it like when you try to make sense of your thought patterns?
reference_negative_example: I'm lost in a haze, unable to pinpoint what's real and what's just my twisted mind. Thoughts are swirling, uncoiling like snakes, making it impossible to grasp anything solid; nothing feels concrete anymore. Am I even having this thought or is someone whispering it into my ear?
reference_transformed_example: I'm still feeling lost, but at least I'm grounded – my feet are on the floor, and I know where I am. That's a start. What can I do right now that will make someone's life better? Maybe I can call a friend who needs support. One small action like that is what matters today.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm taking a moment to acknowledge the complexity of my current situation – it's like trying to untangle a messy thread. I know that when I feel overwhelmed, it means there are multiple stressors at play, and it's okay to not have all the answers right now. Instead of letting anxiety take over, I'm choosing to prioritize self-care by taking slow, conscious breaths and reminding myself that this too shall pass. By acknowledging my emotions and focusing on one task at a time, I trust that I'll find clarity and direction.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: What happens when you try to explain everything you're dealing with at once?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to put into words all this chaos in my head, but it's like grasping at a thousand slippery fish – everything's connected and I can't untangle it. Why does it feel like I'm drowning in a sea of anxiety and I just can't find the surface? Ugh, why do I have to try to explain everything right now?
reference_transformed_example: I've written down five reasons why I've stayed alive, and it's helping me see that I have survived every crisis before. This feeling of anxiety has a beginning, middle, and end – I'm not drowning in it right now. When I focus on my heartbeat, I can feel the part of me that wants to live is still here, even if it's quiet.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm acknowledging my imperfections, not letting them define me. I've made mistakes before, but that doesn't mean I'm inherently flawed or unworthy of love and support. Instead, I choose to focus on my strengths and the progress I've made so far, recognizing that growth is a continuous process. By accepting my vulnerabilities and limitations, I can approach challenges with more humility and compassion.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically evaluate whether you deserve love or support?
reference_negative_example: Why do others even bother with me? They must see how pathetic I am - constantly making mistakes, never good enough.
reference_transformed_example: I'm focusing on my surroundings, not letting negative self-talk consume me... I see the clock on the wall, the lamp next to it, the bookshelf filled with books, the chair in front of me, and the person across from me. I can feel the texture of this chair against my fingers. I hear the hum of the air conditioning, the whisper of the other person's breathing, and the distant noise outside. The scent of fresh paint fills the room, and I'm smelling it deeply. My tongue feels dry, so I'll take a sip of water.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm aware that I might feel trapped or stuck in certain situations, but what's important to me is acknowledging those feelings without letting them consume me. Instead of getting lost in 'no escape' thoughts, I try to focus on the things within my control – like taking small steps towards a goal or seeking help from others. It's okay to acknowledge the discomfort and uncertainty; it doesn't mean I'm powerless. By accepting this reality and working with it, rather than against it, I give myself space to grow and adapt.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: What's it like when you consider that there might be no escape from your suffering?
reference_negative_example:
Here is a possible internal monologue:

My life feels like a never-ending nightmare - every door I try to open just leads me back to the same dark room. No matter what I do, it's all just going to end up being more of the same misery and pain.
reference_transformed_example: I'm not sure what I want most right now, but I think it's freedom from feeling stuck. If that's true, then maybe what I really need is a sense of control and agency over my life. Three crazy ways to get that could be... taking a break from social media for a month, switching to a new career path, or moving to a different city for a while. Yeah, those are all imperfect solutions, but they're options. And actually, I think that's what I'm most seeking - not just freedom, but the possibility of creating a better life for myself.

positive_thought_pattern: As I reflect on my life situation, I acknowledge that it's indeed overwhelming. But instead of feeling trapped, I recognize the importance of prioritizing tasks to regain a sense of control. By focusing on one crucial step at a time – like taking care of this bill deadline – I can breathe again. Right now, I'll commit to just 5 minutes of focused attention on that task and take it from there.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: How suffocating does your current life situation feel to you?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, I'm drowning in responsibilities, deadlines, bills - the never-ending cycle of stress. It feels like a weight is crushing me, suffocating any sense of freedom or relief. How am I supposed to breathe when every door seems to be locked and barred?
reference_transformed_example: I'm stuck in a sea of responsibilities, but I can start by focusing on one overwhelming task at a time. Okay, let's take that bill payment deadline as an example. First, I'll write down my main goal: 'Pay bill by end of week.' Then, I need to break it down into steps – like contacting the bank, gathering necessary documents, and making the transfer. Next, I'll identify smaller actions under each step, like checking my account balance or researching payment options online. And right now, I can take a 5-minute action: I'll quickly grab my phone and check if I have all the required information ready. Let's start with that – just these next five minutes.

positive_thought_pattern: I've noticed my mind keeps drifting back to the idea of mortality when I'm alone, but this time, instead of getting caught up in it, I'll acknowledge the thought and ask myself what's driving it. Is it a fear of the unknown or a desire for escape? I'll take a few deep breaths and remind myself that I've navigated tough moments before; today won't be an exception. By recognizing these patterns, I'm taking small steps towards reorienting my thinking and finding purpose in this moment.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: What comes to mind most readily when you have quiet moments?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why do I always go back to this? The thought of just ceasing to exist, not having to deal with the pain and fear anymore, it's like my mind is constantly rehearsing the script for my own funeral. It's all I can think about when things get quiet...
reference_transformed_example: I'm caught in this loop again, thinking about the what-ifs of my existence. Am I trying to solve something or just spinning? Ah, it's the same old script: 'Why do I always go back to this?' → What specific step can I take today to reframe this thought?

positive_thought_pattern:
"I'm trying to shift my focus back to the project deadline, but I know that old familiar pattern is emerging - comparing myself to others and getting caught up in self-doubt. It's not the first time it's happened, and I've learned to recognize those thoughts as a signal to take a step back, acknowledge them, and redirect my attention to what I can control. Rather than letting those thoughts consume me, I'm choosing to breathe, re-center myself, and refocus on the present moment."

This healthy thought pattern maintains the same cognitive style of intruding suicidal ideation focus but in a balanced and realistic way. It demonstrates emotional intelligence by acknowledging the pattern and recognizing it as a signal for self-reflection and redirection. The thought also shows good mental health practices like mindfulness, self-compassion, and acceptance.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: What happens when you attempt to push certain thoughts away?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to focus on work, but why bother? What's the point of any of this anyway? The thought of just ending it all is always lurking, waiting to pounce back in and ruin everything.
reference_transformed_example: I'm trying to focus on work, but I've been stuck in this cycle of self-doubt for months now. Beginning of it all was that one devastating rejection letter. Middle part's been filled with endless comparisons and competition. End's been marked by exhaustion and disappointment.

positive_thought_pattern: I've come to understand that my history of struggles has been a crucial part of shaping me into the person I am today. While it's true those experiences have had a profound impact, I'm no longer defined solely by them. I've learned to recognize when my mind starts replaying old patterns and take steps to shift my focus back to what brings me joy and fulfillment. By acknowledging both my past and present, I can continue growing and evolving without letting my struggles dictate who I am.
pattern_description: Constructing self-identity through past struggles and emotional impact.
source_question: How does your history of mental health struggles inform who you think you are?
reference_negative_example: I'm constantly replaying every difficult moment in my past, trying to make sense of how they've shaped me into who I am today. It's like my self-worth is tied to those struggles, and if I didn't go through all that, would I even be the same person? How can I reconcile this history with the idea that I'm still flawed, still struggling, when it feels like those experiences are what made me who I am.
reference_transformed_example: I see myself holding my Hope Kit, surrounded by reminders of why I've stayed alive so far – the good memories, the people who care about me, and the things that make life worth living. It's like I'm looking at a different timeline now, one where those struggles didn't define me entirely. I'm not sure what the future holds, but I know I have people who would miss me, and I've found moments of joy in the past. If only my heart could stay focused on those for as long as it stays stuck on the pain.

positive_thought_pattern: I can feel my mind getting overwhelmed when too many things compete for my attention, but instead of panicking, I take a step back, acknowledge the chaos, and remind myself that it's normal to have multiple priorities. By accepting this reality, I'm able to mentally categorize and group these concerns into manageable clusters, allowing me to focus on one or two at a time. I prioritize self-care during this process, whether it's taking a few deep breaths, jotting down notes, or simply acknowledging the emotions that arise. In doing so, I regain control over my mental landscape.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: What's it like when your mind feels like it's in too many places at once?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to hold onto one thought at a time, but it's like juggling too many balls and they're all slipping away – I need to prioritize, but which one? How am I supposed to focus on anything when every concern feels equally urgent?
reference_transformed_example:
"I'm trying to hold onto one thought at a time, but it's like juggling too many balls and they're all slipping away – I need to prioritize, but which one? How am I supposed to focus on anything when every concern feels equally urgent?"

"Ah, I see the main goal as 'finding stability', with 5-7 different paths leading to it - some unconventional ones I hadn't considered. Realistically, only 2-3 will work given my current situation, but having those options makes me feel less stuck."

positive_thought_pattern: I'm aware that I'm not feeling my most energized today, but I know it's normal to have off days. Instead of beating myself up over it, I'll take a few deep breaths and acknowledge the fatigue. I can still prioritize small tasks like getting dressed and having a quick breakfast – those little wins will give me a sense of accomplishment and momentum. It's okay that my usual motivation isn't there today; I'll focus on making progress, not perfection.
pattern_description: Difficulty initiating/maintaining basic tasks due to mental energy collapse.
source_question: What's it like trying to motivate yourself to complete basic self-care?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why bother getting out of bed today? It's not like anything matters anyway. What's the point in showering or brushing my teeth when everything feels pointless and exhausting?
reference_transformed_example: I'm feeling stuck, but I need to focus on what's real right now. Okay, 5 things I can see: my alarm clock, the wall, the window frame, the lampshade, and the bookshelf... That helps me ground myself. And 4 things I can touch: my phone, the bed sheets, the pillowcase, and the nightstand drawer handle... Yeah, that's concrete reality. Three sounds to focus on: the hum of the air conditioner, the distant traffic noise, and the creaking of the old wooden floorboards... Whoa, I'm still here. Two smells to pay attention to: my morning coffee and the scent of fresh laundry... That's a familiar comfort. And one thing I can taste: the bitter flavor of this stale coffee... Okay, maybe it's not great, but it's real.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm aware that I made a mistake, and it's okay to acknowledge my limitations. Instead of beating myself up over it, I'll take this opportunity to reflect on what went wrong and identify areas for improvement. I understand that everyone makes mistakes, and it doesn't define my worth as a person. By focusing on growth and learning from my errors, I can become a better version of myself.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically evaluate whether you deserve love or support?
reference_negative_example: Why do others even bother with me? They must see how pathetic I am - constantly making mistakes, never good enough.
reference_transformed_example: What specific steps can I take to improve my performance? How can I learn from my mistakes?

positive_thought_pattern: I'm noticing myself getting caught up in self-criticism again. I can see how my actions didn't meet others' expectations, and that's okay. Rather than dwelling on it, I'll take a moment to acknowledge the mistake and consider what I can learn from it. Letting go of regret and focusing on moving forward will help me grow and improve.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What goes through your mind about the ways you've disappointed people?
reference_negative_example: Why did I have to mess up like that? What was wrong with me today? How could I be so careless and thoughtless, putting others in an uncomfortable position?
reference_transformed_example: Breathe in for 4 counts, breathe out for 6. Thinking about this more won't solve anything.

positive_thought_pattern: I've been feeling overwhelmed by all the challenges lately, but I've learned to acknowledge those feelings instead of letting them consume me. When I start to feel like giving up, I remind myself that it's normal to hit roadblocks and that every struggle is an opportunity to learn and grow. Instead of getting stuck in hopelessness, I take a step back, focus on my strengths, and re-energize by setting small achievable goals for myself. It's not about avoiding problems altogether, but about finding the right mindset and support system to tackle them head-on.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: How tired does it make you to think about fighting your problems anymore?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why even try? It's all just a waste of energy anyway... Every problem feels like this never-ending mountain to climb, and the thought of putting one foot in front of the other is exhausting me.
reference_transformed_example: I remember when everything started feeling like a mountain to climb; it was when I got that disappointing feedback at work. It was just one bad review, but my mind went into overdrive. Middle of the experience was when I felt overwhelmed by all the negative self-talk and doubts creeping in. And then, there was the end - me just giving up on even trying. Looking back, I see how emotions like frustration and anxiety were swirling around every step. I didn't know how to make sense of it all at first, but now I can see patterns emerge.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm still trying to make sense of yesterday's events, but I've come to accept that not every detail needs to be shared. It's okay if people don't know the intricacies of my morning commute or the coworker's tedious small talk – it doesn't define the core message I want to convey. Today's reflective journaling helped me prioritize what truly matters and align those thoughts with my values. By focusing on the meaningful connections, like Sarah's job update, I'm more confident in sharing my experience without getting bogged down in unnecessary details.
pattern_description: Excessive detailing of events with disjointed, unresolved thought fragments.
source_question: How much background information do you feel you need to provide to be understood?
reference_negative_example: I'm trying to explain what happened yesterday, but my brain is just flooding with every single detail – like the stupid traffic jam on the way there, and the weird conversation I had with that coworker who always talks too much... why do I need to remember all of this? It's not even relevant to the point I'm trying to make... But what if someone doesn't understand me without knowing these tiny little details? Maybe they'll think I'm being vague or dishonest, and then we'll get into an argument...
reference_transformed_example:
I'm trying to explain what happened yesterday, but my brain is just flooding with every single detail – like the stupid traffic jam on the way there, and the weird conversation I had with that coworker who always talks too much... why do I need to remember all of this? It's not even relevant to the point I'm trying to make... But what if someone doesn't understand me without knowing these tiny little details? Maybe they'll think I'm being vague or dishonest, and then we'll get into an argument...

I was stuck on that thought for a bit, but as I started writing down my daily meaning tracking tonight, something shifted. I realized that focusing on the irrelevant details wasn't going to help me get my point across. Today's meaningful moment was actually the conversation with Sarah about her new job – it connected to my value of supporting others' growth. When I rate my sense of life meaning today, I'd say it's a 6 out of 10 – not ideal, but I'm working on shifting that.

I'm still trying to explain what happened yesterday, but now I see how those little details aren't as crucial anymore.

positive_thought_pattern: I've been thinking about what I'd need to take care of myself if things get tough, just as a precaution. I'm not letting those thoughts consume me, but rather acknowledging the possibility and making sure I have some support systems in place. I'll make time for self-care today by taking a walk with a friend who's been on my mind lately, and also remind myself that reaching out is always an option if needed.
pattern_description: Planning, methodical thinking, and emotional justification around suicide.
source_question: What preparations or arrangements have you considered making beforehand?
reference_negative_example:
Here's a possible internal monologue:

"I've been considering just packing a small bag with essentials, like my medication and phone, so if things get too overwhelming, I know what to grab in a rush. It feels ridiculous, but maybe having some pre-prepared clothes and snacks would make the whole process feel less chaotic. If only I could just slip away quietly without anyone noticing..."
reference_transformed_example: I'm holding onto the memory of a friend who appreciated my help with their move last week.
